captions.text:
Okay, let me get this out of the way: white
holes are almost definitely not a real thing
that can be found in nature.

So keep that in mind when I say...we might
have seen one?
(INTRO)

In theory, white holes are black holes that
are going backwards.
In theory.

A black hole, as you know, is a giant object
that sucks stuff into a singularity - a single

point of infinite density - from which there
is no escape.

So a white hole would be an object that expels
matter from a singularity...and you’d never
be able to enter it.

White holes only exist in math. But in 2006,
we saw an explosion of light out in deep space
that we can't explain any other way.
It's...even weirder than it sounds.

In reality, a white hole would violate the
second law of thermodynamics. This says that

the amount of entropy in the universe can
only stay the same or increase. It can never
decrease.

Entropy is often described as disorder, but
it's more like a measure of how many different

states that particles in a system can be in
at any given moment.

Like, if you have a piano, and you throw it
in a woodchipper, you’ve increased the entropy

of the piano. Because a pile of chopped-up
piano splinters can be in lots and lots of

different configurations while still being...a
pile of splinters.

But these piano splinters can really only
be in one, very specific state in order to
be a piano.
At least ... a piano that works.

So, black holes are great at increasing entropy!
They’re the universe's woodchippers: shredding

entire stars into pulp, and leaving only a
whiff of radiation.

But you can't load your pile of piano splinters
into the woodchipper, and run the thing backwards

to get a piano again. That would decrease
entropy, which is not allowed. And if white

holes existed, that's essentially what they’d
do.

So why does anyone think white holes might
exist in the first place?

Well, they were first proposed as a kind of
mathematical oddity, because of Einstein’s
theories of relativity.

One of the many endearing quirks of relativity
is that it doesn't care whether you play time

backward or forward. If time can go in one
direction, it can just as easily go in the
other.

So if black holes are a thing, then white
holes - which are black holes played backward
- can also be a thing.

But just because relativity says time can
go in both directions, in practice it pretty
much sticks to one, as we all know.

So even if a white hole did somehow occur,
it would be incredibly unstable. Because the

universe DOES NOT LIKE IT when you break the
laws of physics! So a real white hole would

probably only last for a few seconds before
it collapsed in on itself to become a black
hole.

Which brings us back to the explosion we saw
in 2006.

Detected by NASA’s Swift satellite on June
14, it was a huge gamma ray burst: the highest-energy

type of explosion possible, a million trillion
times more energetic than the Sun.
And it lasted for…102 seconds.

Scientists believe that gamma ray bursts only
last that long during supernovas. But this

one, labeled GRB 060614, didn't have a supernova
to go with it.

As far as we can tell, it was an explosion
of white hot light that came from nowhere,
and then vanished.

And while white holes remain incredibly, stupendously,
ridiculously unlikely...that's pretty much
exactly what we think one would look like.

Some physicists have offered other explanations
for what it might’ve been -- like a shock

wave from neutron star torn apart by a black
hole, or maybe two neutron stars colliding.

But events like these only release energy
for two seconds at most -- not a minute and
a half.

So. White holes in nature are as impossible
as a thing can be, while still being technically
possible.

But they are technically possible. And until
we see another explosion like the one in 2006

that we could hopefully learn more from, we’ll
just have to wait, and wonder.

Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow
Space! And thanks to all of our Subbable subscribers

who make this channel possible! If you’d
like to support us and score some cool gear,
go to subbable.com/scishow to learn more.

And if you have questions or ideas for an
episode you’d like to see, you can find

us on Facebook and Twitter and in the comments
below, and if you want to keep getting smarter

with us, just go to YouTube.com/scishowspace
and subscribe!

comments.author: 175griffin

comments.text:
I don't know too much about this infinite density black hole thing. But I 
will share what I have been told from Astronomy class.

Black holes are primarily formed from high mass stars when they die - they 
run out of fuel. This causes fusion to stop, and since fusion is the force 
fighting against and balancing out gravity in stars, gravity is allowed to 
run rampant. Gravity will crush the star in on itself, and granted that it 
is a star of high enough mass, it will be crushed down to an infinitely 
small point. THIS DOES NOT MEAN INFINITE MASS. It means infinite density.
The black hole will have something called an event horizon, within which 
light (and therefor nothing else) can resist getting sucked into the 
singularity, due to gravity. Please note: this event horizon is very tiny. 
If you were to force our sun down to the size of a singularity and create a 
black hole (and technically any object with mass could create a 
proportionate black hole if somehow crushed down enough), the orbits of the 
planets would be unchanged. this is because the MASS stays the same (and 
therefor the gravity effect a bit out from the even horizon), disregarding 
whatever is absorbed after the fact. 
Bottom line: The literal definition of a singularity is a point of infinite 
density. It's perfectly possible, and the math works out. To be able to 
understand things on a galactic/cosmic level you have to kinda ditch your 
closed minds.﻿

comments.text:
White Holes they do exist indeed!!  Why??!! Becuase Black Holes are not 
everlasting or eternal. White Hole as a such is the End-life of the Black 
Hole, not as has ben suggested by some to be its "exit point"!! If we look 
at the Big Bang, then Big Bang is just another "Super-Gigantic" White Hole. 
The problem or the "treat" here is that how many Black-Holes are "needed" 
to create a White Hole??!! At some point even the Black Holes, they reach 
their "breaking point" - collapse. So therefore White Holes are End of the 
End and the New starting point of everything - Time and Space!! I think 
that Nietzsche nailed the final nail to science and our "understanding" of 
how the Universe "work" and what it is, when he described everything as 
EWIGE WIEDERHOLUNG - in english ETERNAL REPETITiON!! Eternal repetition 
means that Time and Space, they start, later they reach their end and 
collapse, and later they explode Big bang. and start again from scratch!! 
Cheers﻿

This reminds me of a theory I heard many years ago. I can't remember all 
the details about it, or any of the science that explained it, but the 
basic idea was that a black hole is like a tunnel through space, one that 
near instantly transmits matter from one part of space to another.

If this theory were to be even partially correct, in that black holes are 
the entrances to these space-tunnels, could a white hole than be the exit? 
One where the matter that is sucked in by a black hole and vanishes is 
expelled back into space?﻿
comments.author: 0megaPr0t0c0l

comments.text:
I've always thought it a possibility, however unlikely, that a black hole 
gets too dense to hold everything that it sucks up; then, it must spits its 
contents out of its other side, namely through a white hole. Because there 
is so much stuff, for lack of a better word, that comes out of the black 
hole, the matter that shoots out of the white hole creates a new universe. 
This could be the solution to the start of our universe. Our universe came 
from a black hole which was too dense, shooting all of its matter out 
through a white hole. By this hypothesis, our universe was created by a 
preexisting universe. However, this hypothesis still wouldn't solve the 
problem of where everything originated from. I know that this might sound 
like a crazy,completely improbable hypothesis; it is not impossible, at 
least not yet; however, this hypothesis is not necessarily possible either.﻿

unlikely that a white hole should briefly exist every now and then.﻿

The accretion methodology of planet formation never made sense, especially 
in a charge neutral vacuum as the standard cosmological model suggests. 

There is more that we don't know than do....yet we always act with such

gravitational forces makes little sense since gravity is 10^39 weaker than 
the electromagnetic force. 

Gravity centric cosmological models make less and less sense all the time.

comments.author: CeaoS

comments.text:
+Captain Foxy Like +CeaoS said, the solar system is not an example of a 
closed system. It's an open system because energy from the rest of the 
universe can "enter" it. This is also why anyone who says life/evolution as 
science explains it is impossible because of entropy is also wrong. Plus 
you have to consider that that initial ball of gas actually has a massive 
amount of gravitational potential energy from all those particles being 
separated from each other in space, which is released as heat as it 
condenses and eventually "ignites" into a protostar and then star, and a 
system losing potential energy means its entropy is increasing.

I don't understand the analogy; a white-hole COULD spit out stellar 
'wood-chips' without decreasing entropy.  I mean, a black hole would not 
ingest a star, then its corresponding white hole (if there is such a thing) 
spew out the star in a more ordered state, would it?  

I like to imagine the whole thing as the white hole as being the exhaust 
vent of our galactic wood-chipper.  Or am I missing something?  

Is it that in the black hole, entropy is at a maximum and in ANY instance 
of "white-hole-spew" entropy decreases?  If that's the case, I understand.﻿

nothingness.﻿

comments.author: Robert Shipman

comments.text:
+Jo Jony You're dealing with something that has zero volume though. Did you 
not pass fifth grade science or math?

Let me do the math for you.
Let's say a black hole has a mass of 1 gram. And using the formula density 
= mass/volume.

d = m/v
d = 1/0

If you're following along on your calculator, you'll probably realize at 
this point you're getting a strange reading. Why?

d = infinity

Because even though you have a finite mass you have zero volume, making it 
infinitely dense. Even more dense than you (if such a thing is possible).

comments.author: Rana Kamikaze

comments.text:
+Wan Pelar assuming you meant "The 'set' of all the possible intervals 
between A and B", the two sets you mentioned are in fact the same type of 
infinity, the same size if you wish. Why? Because there exists a bijection 
between them. Look into the work of Cantor if you want to know something 
more about this (fascinating) topic :).

+Rana Kamikaze Physicist don't like infinities just as you don't :), so I 
grant you that we would be very surprised if we could actually see an 
object with infinite density (see naked singularity and cosmic censorship). 
But technically even finite mass when compressed to infinitely small volume 
has infinite density. Since density is a ratio of mass/volume, there are 2 
independent limits that could make this ratio infinite: infinite mass, 
and/or infinitely small volume.
comments.author: Ľuboš Bičian

comments.text:
There are different sizes of infinity. Like which is bigger:

A) The sum of all the possible intervals between 1 and 2

B) The sum of all the possible intervals between 1 and 10

You know B) must be bigger, but yet they're both infinite.

I don't understand why entropy is a factor preventing these from existing. 
These aren't closed systems, so the second law isn't applicable. In other 
words, sure, they may be decreasing entropy near them, but that just means 
that in some other place, the entropy is increasing much more so that the 
net change is still positive. ﻿
